lines.text: Enter CORNWALL, REGAN, GONERIL, EDMUND, and Servants

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Post speedily to my lord your husband; show him this letter: the army of France is landed. Seek out the villain Gloucester.
Exeunt some of the Servants

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Hang him instantly.

lines.speaker: goneril
lines.text: Pluck out his eyes.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our sister company: the revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding. Advise the duke, where you are going, to a most festinate preparation: we are bound to the like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us. Farewell, dear sister: farewell, my lord of Gloucester. How now! where's the king?
Enter OSWALD

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: My lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence: Some five or six and thirty of his knights, Hot questrists after him, met him at gate; Who, with some other of the lords dependants, Are gone with him towards Dover; where they boast To have well-armed friends.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Get horses for your mistress.

lines.speaker: goneril
lines.text: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Edmund, farewell. Go seek the traitor Gloucester, Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us. Though well we may not pass upon his life Without the form of justice, yet our power Shall do a courtesy to our wrath, which men May blame, but not control. Who's there? the traitor?
Exeunt GONERIL, EDMUND, and OSWALD
Exeunt other Servants
Enter GLOUCESTER, brought in by two or three

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Ingrateful fox! 'tis he.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Bind fast his corky arms.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: What mean your graces? Good my friends, consider You are my guests: do me no foul play, friends.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Bind him, I say.
Servants bind him

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Unmerciful lady as you are, I'm none.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find--
REGAN plucks his beard

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done To pluck me by the beard.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: So white, and such a traitor!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Naughty lady, These hairs, which thou dost ravish from my chin, Will quicken, and accuse thee: I am your host: With robbers' hands my hospitable favours You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Be simple answerer, for we know the truth.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom?

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: To whose hands have you sent the lunatic king? Speak.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: I have a letter guessingly set down, Which came from one that's of a neutral heart, And not from one opposed.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Cunning.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: And false.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Where hast thou sent the king?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: To Dover.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril--

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Wherefore to Dover? Let him first answer that.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: I am tied to the stake, and I must stand the course.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Wherefore to Dover, sir?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Because I would not see thy cruel nails Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs. The sea, with such a storm as his bare head In hell-black night endured, would have buoy'd up, And quench'd the stelled fires: Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain. If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time, Thou shouldst have said 'Good porter, turn the key,' All cruels else subscribed: but I shall see The winged vengeance overtake such children.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: See't shalt thou never. Fellows, hold the chair. Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: He that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help! O cruel! O you gods!

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: One side will mock another; the other too.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: If you see vengeance,--

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: Hold your hand, my lord: I have served you ever since I was a child; But better service have I never done you Than now to bid you hold.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: How now, you dog!

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I'd shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: My villain!
They draw and fight

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus!
Takes a sword, and runs at him behind

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him. O!
Dies

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vile jelly! Where is thy lustre now?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: All dark and comfortless. Where's my son Edmund? Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature, To quit this horrid act.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Out, treacherous villain! Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us; Who is too good to pity thee.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: O my follies! then Edgar was abused. Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell His way to Dover. How is't, my lord? how look you?
Exit one with GLOUCESTER

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: I have received a hurt: follow me, lady. Turn out that eyeless villain; throw this slave Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace: Untimely comes this hurt: give me your arm.
Exit CORNWALL, led by REGAN

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: I'll never care what wickedness I do, If this man come to good.

lines.speaker: third servant
lines.text: If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters.

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: Let's follow the old earl, and get the Bedlam To lead him where he would: his roguish madness Allows itself to any thing.

lines.speaker: third servant
lines.text: Go thou: I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face. Now, heaven help him!
Exeunt severally
